subject: Photography
title: Top Lighting: Noon and Overhead
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Top Lighting: Noon and Overhead.

hook.text: Light from directly above creates deep eye sockets and chin shadows. It's the harshest, least flattering angle.

buildup.text: At noon, the sun sits directly overhead. Shadows fall straight down, eyes become dark pits, noses cast black lines.

discovery.text: This is why photographers avoid midday sun for portraits. The overhead angle is brutal and unforgiving.

twist.text: But top light works beautifully for certain moods â€” mystery, menace, isolation. Horror films love it.

climax.text: Understanding why noon light is harsh teaches you when to avoid it â€” and rare cases when to embrace it.

punchline.text: Noon sun is a bully. Work around it â€” or use it.

quiz.question: Why is midday sun generally unflattering for portraits?
options: Overhead light creates deep shadows under eyes and noses
